title: Vector Space Type Schema
description: Schema defining specific types of vector spaces and their properties within the UOR framework

definition.formal: A Hilbert space H is a complete inner product space, i.e., a vector space with an inner product ⟨·,·⟩ that is complete with respect to the norm induced by the inner product: ||x|| = √⟨x,x⟩.
definition.informal: A vector space with a notion of distance and angle that is complete (has no 'gaps') with respect to the distance induced by the inner product.
definition.axiomatic: A vector space H over the field of real or complex numbers equipped with an inner product ⟨·,·⟩ such that the norm defined by ||x|| = √⟨x,x⟩ makes H a complete metric space.
definition.constructive: Can be constructed as the completion of an inner product space with respect to the norm induced by the inner product.

properties.scalarField: Real numbers ℝ or complex numbers ℂ
algebraicProperties: complete with respect to induced norm
orthogonal projections onto closed subspaces exist
orthogonal decomposition with respect to closed subspaces
topologicalProperties: separable (may have a countable dense subset)

relationToOtherTypes.relationship: Every Hilbert space is a Banach space, but not every Banach space is a Hilbert space
A Hilbert space is a complete inner product space
L² spaces are canonical examples of Hilbert spaces
Finite-dimensional Euclidean spaces are Hilbert spaces

canonicalExamples.name: Euclidean Space
canonicalExamples.description: n-dimensional real space with the standard dot product
properties: standard dot product as inner product

canonicalExamples.name: Complex Euclidean Space
canonicalExamples.description: n-dimensional complex space with the standard Hermitian inner product

canonicalExamples.name: L² Space
canonicalExamples.description: Space of square-integrable functions on a measure space (X, μ)
properties: inner product via integration: ⟨f,g⟩ = ∫ f·g̅ dμ
functions are identified if they differ only on sets of measure zero

canonicalExamples.name: Sequence Space
properties: natural isomorphism with sequences of Fourier coefficients of L² functions

factorizationRules.primeElements: In a Hilbert space, the prime elements are the elements of an orthonormal basis. Every Hilbert space has an orthonormal basis, which in the infinite-dimensional case may require the Axiom of Choice to construct.
factorizationRules.basisDefinition: An orthonormal basis for a Hilbert space H is a set of orthonormal vectors {eₐ} such that every vector in H can be uniquely expressed as a convergent (in the norm topology) linear combination of basis elements.
factorizationRules.decompositionProcess: Every vector v in a Hilbert space can be expressed as v = Σₐ ⟨v,eₐ⟩eₐ where {eₐ} is an orthonormal basis. For infinite-dimensional spaces, this sum represents the limit of finite partial sums.
factorizationRules.uniquenessProperties: The coefficients in the basis expansion (⟨v,eₐ⟩) are uniquely determined by the vector v and the basis {eₐ}. This provides a unique factorization in terms of prime elements.
factorizationRules.dependenceRelations: A set of vectors is linearly dependent in a Hilbert space if one of the vectors can be expressed as a convergent linear combination of the others, or more generally if there exists a non-trivial convergent linear combination that equals the zero vector.

dualSpace.description: For a Hilbert space H, the dual space H* (the space of continuous linear functionals on H) is naturally isomorphic to H itself via the Riesz representation theorem.
properties: naturally isomorphic to the original space
every continuous linear functional F on H can be represented as F(x) = ⟨x,y⟩ for some unique y in H
dualSpace.relationship: The Riesz representation theorem establishes a canonical isomorphism between H and H*
dualSpace.isomorphism: The dual space H* is isometrically isomorphic to H for any Hilbert space H

tensorProducts.description: The tensor product of two Hilbert spaces H₁ and H₂ can be equipped with an inner product structure to form another Hilbert space H₁ ⊗ H₂
properties: the tensor product of separable Hilbert spaces is separable
dimension is the product of dimensions (for finite-dimensional spaces)
tensorProducts.constructionMethod: First define the inner product on simple tensors: ⟨x₁⊗y₁, x₂⊗y₂⟩ = ⟨x₁,x₂⟩·⟨y₁,y₂⟩, then extend by linearity and complete the resulting inner product space
tensorProducts.basisRelationship: If {eₐ} is an orthonormal basis for H₁ and {fᵦ} is an orthonormal basis for H₂, then {eₐ⊗fᵦ} is an orthonormal basis for H₁ ⊗ H₂

directSums.description: The direct sum of Hilbert spaces can be equipped with an inner product to form another Hilbert space
properties: the direct sum of separable Hilbert spaces is separable
dimension is the sum of dimensions (for finite-dimensional spaces)
orthogonal direct sum for closed subspaces: H = M ⊕ M⊥ for any closed subspace M
directSums.basisRelationship: If {eₐ} is an orthonormal basis for H₁ and {fᵦ} is an orthonormal basis for H₂, then {(eₐ,0)} ∪ {(0,fᵦ)} is an orthonormal basis for H₁ ⊕ H₂

quotientSpaces.description: For a closed subspace M of a Hilbert space H, the quotient space H/M can be naturally identified with M⊥, the orthogonal complement of M
quotientSpaces.construction: Define H/M as the set of equivalence classes [x] where x ~ y if x - y ∈ M. This space is naturally isomorphic to M⊥
properties: the quotient space H/M is itself a Hilbert space
the natural projection H → H/M is continuous
the dimension of H/M equals the codimension of M in H
quotientSpaces.dimensionRelationship: dim(H) = dim(M) + dim(H/M) for finite-dimensional spaces, or in general: dim(H/M) = dim(M⊥)

innerProductSpaces.standardInnerProduct: Depends on the specific Hilbert space. For ℝⁿ, the standard inner product is ⟨x,y⟩ = Σ xᵢyᵢ. For L²(X,μ), it is ⟨f,g⟩ = ∫ f·g̅ dμ.
properties: positive definiteness: ⟨x,x⟩ ≥ 0 with equality iff x = 0
innerProductSpaces.geometricInterpretation: The inner product generalizes the notion of angle and length from Euclidean geometry to abstract vector spaces, allowing for concepts like orthogonality and projection

normSpaces.completeness: A Hilbert space is, by definition, complete with respect to the norm induced by its inner product. This means that every Cauchy sequence converges to an element of the space.

topologicalStructure.naturalTopology: The norm topology induced by the inner product norm
topologicalStructure.compactness: Infinite-dimensional Hilbert spaces are never locally compact; the unit ball is compact only in finite-dimensional Hilbert spaces
topologicalStructure.connectedness: Hilbert spaces are path-connected and simply connected
topologicalStructure.separability: A Hilbert space is separable if and only if it admits a countable orthonormal basis

linearMapProperties.endomorphisms: Bounded linear operators on a Hilbert space form a C*-algebra with the operator norm and the adjoint operation
linearMapProperties.automorphisms: Unitary operators (those preserving the inner product) are the automorphisms of a Hilbert space as an inner product space
linearMapProperties.isomorphismConditions: Two Hilbert spaces are isomorphic if and only if they have the same dimension (where dimension is defined as the cardinality of an orthonormal basis)

specialLinearMaps.name: Orthogonal/Unitary Operators
specialLinearMaps.description: Linear operators that preserve the inner product
properties: spectrum contained in the unit circle

specialLinearMaps.name: Self-Adjoint Operators
specialLinearMaps.description: Linear operators equal to their own adjoint
properties: complete set of eigenvectors (in finite dimensions)

specialLinearMaps.name: Projection Operators
specialLinearMaps.description: Linear operators projecting onto a closed subspace
properties: norm is 0 or 1 (for non-zero orthogonal projections)

specialLinearMaps.name: Compact Operators
specialLinearMaps.description: Linear operators that map bounded sets to relatively compact sets
properties: spectrum is discrete with possible accumulation point at 0
spectral decomposition for self-adjoint compact operators

primeRepresentationContext.primeElementsConcept: In the UOR framework, the prime elements of a Hilbert space are the elements of an orthonormal basis, which are irreducible in the sense that they cannot be expressed as linear combinations of other elements while maintaining orthonormality
primeRepresentationContext.basisAsPrimeElements: An orthonormal basis serves as the set of prime elements for the factorization of vectors in a Hilbert space, with the coefficients in the basis expansion providing the unique factorization
primeRepresentationContext.primitivityCriteria: A unit vector is a prime element if it is part of an orthonormal basis. In infinite-dimensional spaces, different orthonormal bases lead to different sets of prime elements
primeRepresentationContext.coherencePrinciple: The coherence principle for Hilbert spaces ensures that the representation of vectors in terms of an orthonormal basis minimizes the sum of squared coefficients (Parseval's identity)

observerFrames.frameDescription: Viewing the Hilbert space through the lens of a specific orthonormal basis
Viewing the Hilbert space through the eigenbasis of a specific operator
Viewing Hilbert spaces as function spaces with L² inner products

applications.description: Hilbert spaces provide the mathematical foundation for quantum mechanics
Hilbert spaces model signals and provide tools for analysis and processing
Hilbert spaces provide the setting for the weak formulation of PDEs
Hilbert spaces provide the foundation for kernel methods and functional analysis in machine learning
examples: Reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces (RKHS) in kernel methods

theorems.name: Projection Theorem
theorems.statement: For any closed subspace M of a Hilbert space H and any vector x in H, there exists a unique vector y in M such that ||x - y|| is minimized. This vector y is the orthogonal projection of x onto M.
theorems.significance: Enables optimal approximations and forms the basis for many algorithms in Hilbert spaces

theorems.name: Riesz Representation Theorem
theorems.statement: For any continuous linear functional F on a Hilbert space H, there exists a unique vector y in H such that F(x) = ⟨x,y⟩ for all x in H.
theorems.significance: Provides a natural isomorphism between a Hilbert space and its dual, simplifying functional analysis

theorems.name: Spectral Theorem
theorems.statement: Every self-adjoint operator on a Hilbert space has a spectral decomposition. In finite dimensions, this means it is diagonalizable with real eigenvalues.
theorems.significance: Fundamental for understanding operators in quantum mechanics and many other applications

theorems.name: Parseval's Identity
theorems.statement: For any orthonormal basis {eₐ} of a Hilbert space H and any vector x in H, ||x||² = Σₐ |⟨x,eₐ⟩|².
theorems.significance: Connects the norm of a vector to its components relative to an orthonormal basis, generalizing the Pythagorean theorem

keyDevelopments.development: Initial work on integral equations leading to the concept of what would later be called Hilbert spaces
Formal axiomatization of Hilbert spaces and application to quantum mechanics
Riesz representation theorem establishing the duality between Hilbert spaces and their duals
Development of spectral theory for operators on Hilbert spaces
Applications to quantum field theory, signal processing, and functional analysis
